div1.p: Kellogg discusses the display of the "Cuban version" sketches of Cornwell's yellow fever painting, in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, December 9, 1941
div1.p:
GEORGE A. KELLOGG
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N.J.
December 9, 1941 Dear Dr. Hench:

I am glad that you liked the oil sketches of the “Cuban
version” of “The Conquerors”. I know that Mr. Law was most
pleased to hear from you as was Mr. Cornwell.

First, as to the exhibition in Cuba, I talked with Mr.
Hodgman this morning and he said the first important medical
congress to have a meeting where the pictures might be exhibited
will not convene until next fall. He felt that he would be able
to give me definite information in about six weeks which I will
transmit to you immediately. Deferring this show in Cuba should
allow you to go ahead with the plans you have made, and still
make it possible for you to go to Havana later in the year.

As to the keys on the back of the framed prints, we didn't
get the final spelling for these names until some time after
they were printed. They will be corrected if we have a second
edition.

Under separate cover I am sending you ten of the inserts
which appeared in the A.M.A. JOURNAL. We have sent a number to
Gen. Truby so that you need not send him any. We appreciate the
fact that you are exhibiting the oil sketches along with photo-
graphs in your library, so don't hesitate to suggest that I send
you additional framed prints to your colleagues, but rather send
me their names and the pictures will be forwarded.

We are somewhat upset about the declaration of war and I am
going to defer writing about other things until a later date.

Enclosed find a copy of a second letter from Dr. Hutchison.
He certainly has been most appreciative.
Sincerely,
George Kellogg

Dr. Philip S. Hench
The Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota

GAK:L
Enclosures
C O P Y

George A. Kellogg
John Wyeth and Brother
Philadelphia, Penna.
Dear Mr. Kellogg:

The framed print of “Conquerors
of Yellow Fever” has just arrived, and I can't
tell you how thrilled I am to have it. I have
already hung it in a prominent place in my living
room and, as a granddaughter of Walter Reed, I am
very, very proud of it and all that it stands for.
It shall certainly always be one of my most treasured
possessions.

With my most sincere thanks to you
and the management of John Wyeth and Brother, I am,
Most sincerely
(sgd.) Alison Royce
Dec 10 (Mrs. C H.)
